perturbation.original_text: 1.21 "Products" means the ENERGOUS products set forth in Exhibit A, as such Exhibit may be amended from time to time by mutual agreement between the parties, that have been released by ENERGOUS to production, including all Product Updates, which will be deemed to have been added to Exhibit A automatically, without any further action required by the parties, immediately following the release to production date.
perturbation.changed_text: 1.21 "Products" means the ENERGOUS items set forth in Exhibit A, as such Exhibit may be amended from time to time by mutual agreement between the parties, that have been released by ENERGOUS to production, including all Product Updates, which will be deemed to have been added to Exhibit A automatically, without any further action required by the parties, immediately following the release to production date.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'products' to 'items' introduces ambiguity. Throughout the document, 'Products' refers specifically to the technological outputs of ENERGOUS. By changing it to 'items', it's no longer clear if the contract refers to general goods or the specifically designed technological products. This affects any clause which depends on the term 'Products'.

perturbation.original_text: 11.2 Product Warranty. (a) ENERGOUS warrants that (i) when manufactured in accordance with the Approved Production Specifications, and as implemented in a suitable circuit application in accordance with the Product Specifications, the Products and Product Die will conform to the Product Specifications and will be free from defects that could have been avoided in their design; (ii) the Products, any constituent parts or functionality thereof, the Documentation and the Deposit Materials do not infringe any third party's Intellectual Property Rights; (iii) it did not misappropriate any third party's trade secrets in the development of the Products, any constituent parts or functionality thereof, the Documentation or the Deposit Materials; and (iv) when delivered (including any software updates if any), no Product will contain any viruses, "Trojan horses" or other harmful code. The above warranties are valid for a period of [***] from the date of shipment of any Licensed Product to any customer.
perturbation.changed_text: 11.2 Product Warranty. (a) ENERGOUS warrants that (i) when manufactured in accordance with the Approved Production Standards, and as implemented in a suitable circuit application in accordance with the Product Standards, the Products and Product Die will conform to the Product Standards and will be free from defects that could have been avoided in their design; (ii) the Products, any constituent parts or functionality thereof, the Documentation and the Deposit Materials do not infringe any third party's Intellectual Property Rights; (iii) it did not misappropriate any third party's trade secrets in the development of the Products, any constituent parts or functionality thereof, the Documentation or the Deposit Materials; and (iv) when delivered (including any software updates if any), no Product will contain any viruses, "Trojan horses" or other harmful code. The above warranties are valid for a period of [***] from the date of shipment of any Licensed Product to any customer.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'Specifications' to 'Standards' is an internal contradiction because the term 'Specifications' is defined in Section 1.24. By contrast, 'Standards' is a new term. The change affects Section 11.2 (a), where it is stated the products have to be manufactured based on the 'Approved Production Standards, and as implemented in a suitable circuit application in accordance with the Product Standards'. It's now not clear what standards are referenced, and creates uncertainty in the contractual obligations.

perturbation.original_text: 3.3 Tooling. Subject to ENERGOUS' rights in the Product IP and any Third Party IP (including, without limitation, that of any Manufacturing Subcontractors), each party will own all right, title and interest in the physical Tooling procured or generated by that party for the manufacturing, testing and packaging of the Licensed Products. For the avoidance of doubt, as between the parties, ENERGOUS will also continue to own all right, title and interest in and to the firmware, DSP code and GUI software embedded in the Products, including all Intellectual Property Rights embodied therein. Upon the termination of DIALOG's right to manufacture the Licensed Products following any expiration or termination of the Agreement or any Wind Down Period or Continuing Obligation period, as applicable, then all right, title and interest in the Tooling will automatically transfer to ENERGOUS subject to any Third Party IP, and DIALOG will, at ENERGOUS' option, either sell any Tooling in its possession to ENERGOUS at cost or destroy the Tooling and certify in writing as to same.
perturbation.changed_text: 3.3 Tooling. Subject to ENERGOUS' rights in the Product IP and any Third Party IP (including, without limitation, that of any Manufacturing Subcontractors), each party will own all right, title and interest in the physical Instruments procured or generated by that party for the manufacturing, testing and packaging of the Licensed Products. For the avoidance of doubt, as between the parties, ENERGOUS will also continue to own all right, title and interest in and to the firmware, DSP code and GUI software embedded in the Products, including all Intellectual Property Rights embodied therein. Upon the termination of DIALOG's right to manufacture the Licensed Products following any expiration or termination of the Agreement or any Wind Down Period or Continuing Obligation period, as applicable, then all right, title and interest in the Instruments will automatically transfer to ENERGOUS subject to any Third Party IP, and DIALOG will, at ENERGOUS' option, either sell any Instruments in its possession to ENERGOUS at cost or destroy the Instruments and certify in writing as to same.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'Tooling' to 'Instruments' introduces ambiguity about what happens with the actual Tooling. Section 1.30 defines what Tooling are, and encompasses physical items, as well as software and processes. Using the term 'Instruments' and only applying it to some parts of the paragraph creates uncertainty about how the definition of Tooling has been modified.
